awd_titl_txt: MRI-Acquisition: Sputtering System for Developing Novel Germanium Detectors and Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will provide a new sputtering system for developing novel germanium (Ge) detectors and materials research in the Departments of Physics at the University of South Dakota (USD) and at South Dakota State University (SDSU). This instrument will significantly improve the research facility and capability in the state of South Dakota. The device will be used by a number of investigators to develop and test novel germanium detector designs, some with promising applications to dark matter and neutrino detection, others for medical imaging. The equipment and the dedicated detector fabrication laboratory promise to realize an unusually broad spectrum of Broader Impact. This includes advances in medical research, but also more generically, in fields like environmental monitoring or homeland security. In addition, the group has a track record of involving students from underrepresented groups in the research. The planned instrument will enable multidisciplinary research and more than 50 students will be trained.

A sputtering system with a configuration to coat up to 4 inches in diameter and 3 inches in thickness for substrates per batch from both sides by utilizing an in-situ substrate pallet flipping mechanism is planned in this project. Sputtering is a deposition technology involving a gaseous plasma which is generated and confined to a space containing a target (substrate) to be deposited. The surface of the target is eroded by high-energy ions within the plasma, and the liberated atoms travel through the vacuum environment and are deposited into a substrate to form a thin film. The sputtering technology has been used in developing novel Ge detectors by creating amorphous Ge (a-Ge) or a-Si thin films onto high-purity Ge crystals to make electrical contacts, which provide bipolar blocking for electrons and holes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our project successfully met its objectives in advancing materials science and detector technology, delivering outcomes with significant intellectual merit and wide-ranging societal impact. This report offers a comprehensive summary of our key achievements and findings, all made possible through the support of the National Science Foundation (NSF).

At the core of our project was the development and enhancement of Germanium (Ge) detectors, which are vital for a wide array of applications, including nuclear physics, particle physics, medical imaging, and environmental monitoring. One of the major milestones was the successful implementation of a state-of-the-art magnetron sputtering system, positioning us at the forefront of fabricating high-purity Ge detectors. These detectors are crucial for experiments aimed at detecting rare events, such as neutrinoless double-beta decay, which could offer profound insights into the fundamental properties of neutrinos.

A significant breakthrough in our project was the integration of a new automated sputtering machine, which played a pivotal role in refining the process of creating electrical contacts on Ge crystals. Through meticulous experimentation and the application of this advanced technology, we verified that this sputtering machine can reliably produce highly efficient electrical contacts. This advancement not only enhances the overall performance of the detectors, making them more sensitive and accurate, but also accelerates the research process by ensuring consistent and precise results.

The impact of the automated sputtering machine extends beyond our research in physics and materials science, significantly advancing education at institutions in the Midwest, including the University of South Dakota (USD) and South Dakota State University (SDSU). By incorporating this cutting-edge equipment into our curriculum and research activities, we provided students with invaluable hands-on experience in advanced technology, greatly enhancing their learning and better preparing them for future careers in science and engineering. During the grant period, USD successfully trained over 15 students, while SDSU trained two students. Additionally, through outreach activities, more than 20 high school students and 10 K-12 teachers visited the new sputtering machine at the USD lab, further broadening its educational impact and inspiring the next generation of scientists and educators.

Beyond technical advancements, our project offered extensive training opportunities for students and early-career researchers. By engaging them in cutting-edge research and hands-on activities—such as operating the sputtering machine and processing Ge crystals and magnetic materials—we have contributed to the development of a skilled workforce capable of driving future innovations in this field.

The broader impacts of our project extend well beyond the scientific community, influencing various aspects of society and education. One of the most notable outcomes has been the enhancement of educational experiences for students at our institution. We integrated our research findings into the curriculum, particularly in courses like Semiconductor Fundamentals and Fabrication, where students were exposed to real-world applications of the theories they were learning. This hands-on approach not only deepened their understanding but also inspired many to pursue careers in science and engineering.

Our project has also strengthened institutional infrastructure. The acquisition of advanced equipment and the enhancement of laboratory facilities have significantly improved our research capabilities, benefiting not only our current project but also future research endeavors. This development has positioned our institution as a leader in materials science and detector technology, attracting further research opportunities and collaborations.

In addition to the academic and scientific impacts, our project has potential implications for public health and environmental monitoring. The improved Ge detectors developed through our work could be used in medical imaging devices, leading to better diagnostic tools and improved patient outcomes. Moreover, these detectors could be applied in environmental monitoring systems to detect and measure radiation levels, contributing to public safety and environmental protection.
